Black has 3 minor pieces developed to White's none. If he can attack quickly, White's defenses will be unready.
Black has 3 minor pieces developed to White's none. If he can attack quickly, White's defenses will be unready.
Finally developing a piece! But it's too little, too late.

Yet another Queen move! 9 N-QB3 would allow White to castle into relative safety. Now his King will be caught in the center. [If Black tries to win the Q via a pin on the K file, White has just enough time to get away: 9 N-QB3 R-K1 10 O-O-O B-Q3 and the White Q is free to escape the Rook's attack.]

Forcing the Q to move yet again!
With the threat of 11... B-N5 mate! Double checks are probably the most powerful weapon on the chessboard.

A waiting move, hoping White will fall into the trap.
Whoopsie! White got greedy and forgot that the pawn was the only thing preventing...
...this finish. My friend, in a mastery of understatement, sent this with a note reading "Not my best effort." I'd wholeheartedly agree.
